reviews.review_text: I read this straight through because it is so interesting.
WW2 buffs will enjoy this memoir of a very cool and kind lady.
Interesting diary of one area of Italy during WWII  Well organized but could have better maps would be helpful to read other books onIris Origo's life
A wonderful subject but I found it got very boring after the first couple of chapters.  I got lost in the details of the fascist movement's rising and falling, and found the writing rather dull.
Personal account of what went on in 44 and 45.

I bought this book because it was on a reading list for an upcoming trip to this area of Italy.  It was fascinating to relive the tumultuous, tragic events of World War II in this area through the eyes of the writer as she detailed it in her personal diary.  I loved reading the  details of how she and her family helped those in need who passed through their farm, the very touching details of their own losses and their hopeful spirit as the war ended.
Amazing, powerful read. Excellent book for those interested in Tuscany and Italy during WWII.
The day-by-day uncertainty described in this diary is gripping and reveals the stark reality of being at war. Great work.

summary:
The author, an Anglo-American married to an Italian landowner in 1924, found herself raising a family during the civil war and foreign invasion in the remote Tuscan countryside. 

This diary records her concerns to keep her household and sixty orphans together and save a rural community from annihilation. It is a story of confusion and bewilderment as a peasant society is confronted by disaster when, in the space of a few months, a whole way of life is changed completely beyond recognition. It is also a story of tragedy and suffering, of individual courage, generosity and heroism.

'It is jolting to recall, through Origo's sober and self-effacing prose, the atrocious conditions of the summer of 1944, as the Allies fought their way painfully up the peninsula from the beachhead of Anzio.' The Financial Times
